review.title: Probabilistic Model-Based Approach for Heart Beat Detection
review.abstract: Nowadays, hospitals are ubiquitous and integral to modern society. Patients flow in and out of a veritable whirlwind of paperwork, consultations, and potential inpatient admissions, through an abstracted system that is not without flaws. One of the biggest flaws in the medical system is perhaps an unexpected one: the patient alarm system. One longitudinal study reported an 88.8% rate of false alarms, with other studies reporting numbers of similar magnitudes. These false alarm rates lead to a number of deleterious effects that manifest in a significantly lower standard of care across clinics.

metadata.title: Probabilistic Model-Based Approach for Heart Beat Detection

sections.text: Submitted to: COMECON

sections.heading: Probabilistic Model-Based Approach for Heart Beat
sections.text: DetectorHugh Chen University of California Berkeley California, USA hugh.chen {at} berkeley.eduYusuf Erol University of California BerkeleyCalifornia, USA yusufbugraerol {at} berkeley.eduEric Shen University of California BerkeleyCalifornia, USA ericshen {at} berkeley.eduStuart Russell University of California Berkeley California, USA russell {at} cs.berkeley.eduToday, hospitals are ubiquitous and an integral part of modern society. Patients flock in and out of a veritable whirlwind of paperwork, consultations and potential inpatient admissions through an abstract system that is not without flaws. One of the biggest flaws in the medical system is perhaps an unexpected one: the patient alarm system. A longitudinal study reported an 88.8% study of excessive physical alarms, with other studies reporting numbers of similar magnitude.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year, it will be able to inherit the aforementioned consecrated brainless consecrated brainless consecrated brainless consecrated brainless consecrated brainless consecrated brainless consecrated brainless consecrated brainless consecrated.

sections.heading: 2 Physionet
sections.text: Before we go directly into the algorithm, it is worth mentioning Physionet. Physionet is a research resource that provides access to a considerable range of recorded physiological signals and their open source software. In addition, they pose challenges annually, the challenge last year being heart rate detection. We use several of the data sets provided by Physionet to evaluate the performance of our algorithm.

sections.heading: 2.1 Material
sections.text: The first is the Physionet Challenge 2014 training set (set-p1), which is a data set published during the first phase of the challenge (Goldberger et al. 2000 (June 13).There are 100 examples, all relatively clean and without artifacts; the data is typically 10 minutes long or shorter, and each data set contains at least one ECG signal and at least one ABP signal. The sampling rate is also consistent among these examples at 250 samples per second. The next data set is the Physionet Challenge 2014 extended training set (set-p2), consisting of 100 data sets (Goldberger et al. 2000 (June 13).These data sets contain signals that show more noise and artifacts than that of set-p1. The signals in set-p2 are mostly 10 minutes long, although there are occasionally shorter signals. The sampling frequency varies between 250 samples per second and 360 data sets per second.The final data set we use is the Rubicon Foundation (Massachusetts General Hospital / MGH), which is a database with three MGH functions.

sections.heading: 2.2 Related Work
sections.text: The six best algorithms submitted to the Physionet 2014 Challenge, ordered by performance at Physionet, are Pangerc (Pangerc & Jager 2014), Johnson (Johnson, Bechar, Andreotti, Clifford & Oster 2014), Antink (Hoog Antink, Bruser & Leonhardt 2014), De Cooman (De Cooman, Goovaerts, Varon, Widjaja & Huffel 2014), Johannesen (Johannesen, Vicente, Scully, Galeotti & Strauss 2014) and Vollmer (Vollmer 2014). Generally, most of the submissions included a subset of some typical techniques: pre-processing, a combination algorithm and then post-processing. Furthermore, most algorithms used some form of delay implementation, either in their pre-processing or their combination algorithm, to account for ABP delay, which is significantly higher than the ECG signals and the ECG signal capture.

sections.heading: 3 Methods - Algorithm
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Introduction
sections.text: The first equation represents the initialization of state variables corresponding to the previous probability; the second equation represents the propagation model based on other probabilities.

sections.heading: 3.2 Sequential Monte Carlo
sections.text: In the light of a probability calculation and a sequence of observations, it is possible to attempt to estimate the latent states, which is the problem of state estimation ions that also have k as filters: t Method for calculating the posterior distribution of hidden state variables in the face of a sequence of observations. Precise filtering is often insoluble, except in certain cases, but approximate filtering using the particle filter (a Monte Carlo sequential method) is feasible in many applications (Arulampalam, Maskell, Gordon & Clapp 2002) (Doucet & Johansen 2011). The specific method we use is the sequential import sampling resampling (SIR), also known as bootstrap filtering and particle filtering. This representation is based on the approximation of posterior density, p (xt | y0: t, 2001). The specific method we use is sequential import sampling filtering and particle filtering (also known as SIR and resampling).

sections.heading: 4 Methods - Model
sections.text: Our approach is based on the assumption that human physiology follows a pattern that can be modelled in a Bayesian way. Specifically, we construct a DBN that corresponds to human physiology, with static variables defining an observational model. Propagation and observational models are described in the following sections and illustrated in Figure 5. We proceed to use the filtering techniques covered in the previous section to perform state assessments based on the DBN that we have constructed.

sections.heading: 4.3 Performing State Estimation
sections.text: Our particle filter follows SIR, performing three steps recursively: dispersion, weighting and repetition. First, we divide our signals into 25 millisecond windows and calculate the values of the variables of the observation model for each of these windows. Then, the particle filter assigns a prior belief to our set of particles (in our algorithm we use a set of 2000). For the propagation step, we propagate the particles individually according to our transition model to capture the state of the model one step into the future. Next, we calculate a weight for each particle that is representative of the probability of the realized state of this particle, since the observations we made at the appropriate time are the last recursive steps to restore the particles according to the weights we have calculated.

sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: Now that we have established the algorithm, we will discuss the performance of the algorithm on several datasets. In this section, we will compare the results in terms of sensitivity (recall) and positive predictive power (precision). Sensitivity represents the percentage of actual beats that our algorithm comments on, and positive predictive power the percentage of detections that correspond to the actual beats.

sections.heading: 5.2 Results - Overall
sections.text: To generate these results, we took the top entries on Physionet, loaded their entries, and placed them against exactly the same datasets that we used. We then used the Physionet function to compare the annotations generated with the reference persons, and to determine the sensitivity and predictive power for a given dataset. Finally, we have to capture the sensitivity and predictive power of all datasets from one given dataset to another for consistency in our comparisons, while all submissions ran without errors and our algorithms that we were starting from.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: In this section we will discuss some of the interesting features of our algorithm. First, it is important to note that our algorithm is slower than other standard signal acquisition, mainly because it is a simulation based on a filter algorithm. Generally, our algorithm takes 94.33 seconds to run on an online algorithm. This is simply because particle filters process data sequentially. We have shown an example of double annotation in the previous section. To mitigate the duplicate annotations we have, we need to expand our model.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: Based on our results, we find that the use of particle filters based on our DBN model works pretty well. It matches or exceeds the majority of the top submissions for the Physionet 2014 Challenge. In terms of the standard Physionet beat detector GQRS, we are improving in set-p2 by about 4% in both sensitivity and positive predictive power. As a whole, our particle filter serves as strong evidence of the concept that a probabilistic model based on inference approaches can detect heartbeats robustly. Our probabilistic model is not completely perfect, but some of the benefits of our algorithm include: 1. Uses multi-channel information by incorporating the ECG-ABP peak delay (latency). 2. Flexible model - easy to integrate new variables and relationships. 3. Flexible observations - simply turn off GQRS and WABP for other signal processing algorithms. 4. We can be implemented with a physiological perspective.

sections.heading: 8 Acknowledgements
sections.text: We thank Xiao Hu, Quan Ding, Yong Bai, Rebeca Salas-Boni and Daniel Schindler for helpful conversations.

sections.heading: A Propagation Model
sections.text: The dispersion model (transition model) encodes the interdependent evolution of our relevant physiological variables over time. The structure of dependencies can be seen in the figure in section 5.

sections.heading: A.1 RestHR
sections.text: RestHR is a real-world weighted static variable that represents the resting heart of a particular patient, which is simply the expected heart rate of the patient at rest. The previous value is a gauss of the average heart rate determined by the demographic development of the patient. It follows the following static (i.e. identity-related) propagation function: RestHRt + 1 ← RestHRt (4)

sections.heading: A.1.1 Latency
sections.text: In Figure 10, it is possible to see that the heartbeats fall to or very close to the R-peaks of the ECG QRS signals. Conversely, the ABP beats do not fall on the mapped peaks, but reliably well before the peaks. In our model, latency is an integer static variable that represents this relationship between heartbeat and blood pressure. The previous value is a Gaussian value of about 200 milliseconds. It follows the following propagation function: latency cycle + 1 ← latency cycle (5)

sections.heading: A.2 TrueHR
sections.text: TrueHR is a real variable that represents the heart rate of a patient at the present time. The previous value of TrueHR begins as a Gaussian value around the residual HR. Here, norm means the decrease from a Gaussian distribution with a given µ and σ. TrueHR0 ← RestingHR0 + 5 х norm (µ = 0, σ = 1) (6) Since the true heart rate of a patient may vary over a few minutes, whereby the heart rate may vary at rest over a few months, the true heart rate is not a static variable. It obeys the following propagation function: TrueHRt + 1 ←.8 х TrueHRt +.2 х RestHRt + 15 х norm (µ = 0, σ = 1) (7)

sections.heading: A.3 ECGPeak
sections.text: ECGPeak is a boolean weighted variable, which is 1 if there is a beat commented on the current timestep, and otherwise 0. ECGPeak's previous variable starts as 1 with a small probability (time.01). It obeys the following propagation function: ECGPeakt + 1 ← Bernoulli (P) (8) We calculate P dynamically. Over time, the P parameter will change depending on the current values of TrueHR and ECGLastPeak, which is the number of windows per beat based on the current heart rate. First, we define the difference between the current timestep and the last peak as di f = t − ECGLastPeakt. Then we define BeatWindowt = 60 / (window: TrueHRt), which is the number of windows per beat based on the current heart rate. P = binopd f (mod f, BeatWindowt) and the variance of BeatWindowt (Beatf).

sections.heading: A.4 ECGLastPeak
sections.text: ECGLastPeak is an integer variable that represents the last time we believed there was a peak based on ECG. ECGLastPeak is a uniform distribution of integers between [− BeatWindow, − 1]. ECGLastPeak helps to shift the expected position of all heartbeats due to the multimodal value of P in ECGPeak. Uniform sampling means that the predecessor believes that the expected heartbeats can be shifted to cover all possible initializations. It obeys the following propagation function: ECGLastPeakt + 1 = {t + 1 i f ECGPeakt + 1 = = 1 ECGLastPeakt i f ECGPeakt + 1 = = 0In other words, this equation states that ECGLastPeak changes to record the last time ECGLastPeak was 1.

sections.heading: A.5 ABPPeak
sections.text: ABPPeak is a Boolean variable that indicates whether there is a peak based on the ABP and the ECG. Since the ABPPeak should theoretically be in line with the ECGPeak and at the same time take into account the latency, it obeys the following propagation function (even for the previous one): ABPPeakt + 1 ← (t = = ECGLastPeakt + Particle Mean (latency cycle)) (10) Particle Means here means that we take the mean across all particles. Admittedly, this is unorthodox, but it means that we mitigate the problem of double and triple annotations at adjacent locations for the ABPPeak. If the particle filter had a while to learn the latency and let it converge, then this correction would be unnecessary, but as it is, this correction means that the particles of the particle filter at the ABPPeak do not differ excessively.

sections.heading: A.6 ABPLastPeak
sections.text: ABPLastPeak is an integer variable that represents the last time we thought there was a peak on both ECG and ABP. The previous variable starts as ECGLastPeak0 + Latence0. It follows the following propagation function: ABPLastPeakt + 1 = {t + 1 i f ABPPeakt + 1 = = 1 ABPLastPeakt i f ABPPeakt + 1 = = 0

sections.heading: A.7 ECGArtifact and ABPArtifact
sections.text: ECGArti f act and ABPArti f act are Boolean variables that represent whether we believe that there is currently an artifact that is related to either ECGPeak or ABPPeak. Their behavior before and after multiplication is exactly the same. 1 represents an artifact and 0 does not represent an artifact.The earlier belief in the artifacts begins with a small probability (time.01) It obeys the following propagation function: Arti f actt + 1 ← Bernoulli (PA) (11) Here PA represents the Pr (Arti f actt + 1 | Arti f actt) determined by the following conditional probability table: Arti f actt + 1 Pr (Arti f actt + 1 | Arti f actt) 1 1 1 0.99 1 0 0.01 0 0.01 0 0.99This table represents a form of inertia. As there is currently an artifact, the probability that there is still a high probability that there is an artifact.

sections.heading: B Observation Model
sections.text: The observational model (sensor model) encodes our beliefs about the functions we use to derive observations and the probability that the observations correspond to the current states. The structure of dependencies can be seen in the figure in Section 5.

sections.heading: B.1 Annotation Observations
sections.text: That is why we are able to go in search of a solution that will enable us, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, that will enable us to find a solution, and that will enable us to find a solution.

sections.heading: C Heart Rate Observations
sections.text: These are the WABPHR and GQRSHR variables of the model (collectively referred to as HRobs variables), and the observations are derived from the WABPH and GQRS algorithms provided by Physionet. The algorithms simply use a specified window size and have a sliding window for calculating the local heart rate. HRobs observations are set accordingly. We then define the probability of the observations using the following states: Pr (HRobs | States) = normpd f (TrueHR, HRobs, 1 / 4 х HRobs) (14) Here normpd f corresponds to the probability density function of a Gaussian random variable with the given parameters.

sections.heading: D SQI Observations
sections.text: These correspond to the ECQSQI and ABPSQI variables. ECGSQI is calculated by using two signal processing algorithms and comparing them blow by blow. It was derived from the ecgsqi function developed in another Physionet template (Johnson et al. 2014). Specifically, we use gqrs (an unpublished algorithm optimized for sensitivity) and wqrs (an open source algorithm optimized for adult human ECGs). The number of beats that match between the two algorithms is calculated as a real number between 0 and 1. ABPSQI is calculated by checking whether the pressure, mean artery pressure, heart rate, pulse pressure, and a variety of other physiological details are within normal ranges or not. If everything is within a normal range, ABPSQI is 1, otherwise it is 0. This was also derived from the 2006 function, pulse pressure, and a variety of other physiological details are within normal ranges.

sections.heading: D.3 Running BLOG
sections.text: The following shell script was executed to run the blog particle filter. #! / bin / shtime. /.. /.. / blog / dblog\ prop _ fn.dblog\ query.dblog\ obs _ fn.dblog\ obs.dblog\ -n 1000 -o out.jsonThe query.dblog and obs.dblog files contained the data we wanted to load. This command executed the particle filter with 1000 particles and put the output into the out.json file. Note: We will provide the matlab and blog code we wrote at a later date.

referenceMentions.context: One article cites alarm fatigue as one of the top patient safety concerns in hospitals (MacDonald 2007).

The top six algorithms that were submitted to the Physionet 2014 Challenge, ordered by their performance in Physionet are Pangerc (Pangerc & Jager 2014), Johnson (Johnson, Bechar, Andreotti, Clifford & Oster 2014), Antink (Hoog Antink, Bruser & Leonhardt 2014), De Cooman (De Cooman, Goovaerts, Varon, Widjaja & Huffel 2014), Johannesen (Johannesen, Vicente, Scully, Galeotti & Strauss 2014), and Vollmer (Vollmer 2014).
quential Monte Carlo method) is feasible in many realworld applications (Arulampalam et al., 2002; Doucet and Johansen, 2008).

The ECGSQI is calculated by comparing the results from two of Physionet’s ECG signal detectors, and the ABPSQI is calculated by checking that the detections are within certain physiological boundaries (Johnson et al. 2014) (Sun, Reisner, Saeed & Mark 2005) (Sun 2006).

Their QRS detector (repdet) provided a much improved performance over GQRS on set-p2 in particular, likely due to their inclusion of a step in the detector to identify double annotations (paced beats) (Silva et al. 2015) (Pangerc & Jager 2014).
Only Pangerc, who relied on their reimplemented beat detection algorithm (repdet) outperformed our own (Silva et al. 2015).

metadata.abstractText: The parameters of temporal models such as dynamic Bayesian networks may be viewed in the Bayesian context as static or atemporal variables that influence the transition probabilities at every time step. Particle filters fail for models that include such variables, while methods that use Gibbs sampling of parameter variables may incur a per-sample cost that grows linearly with the length of the observation sequence. Storvik (2002) devised a method for incremental computation of exact sufficient statistics that, for some cases, reduces the per-sample cost to a constant. In this paper, we demonstrate a connection between Storvik’s filter and a Kalman filter in parameter space and establish more general conditions under which it works. Drawing on an analogy to the extended Kalman filter, we develop and analyze, both theoretically and experimentally, a Taylor approximation to the parameter posterior that allows Storvik’s method to be applied to a broader class of models. Our experiments on both synthetic examples and real applications show improvement over existing methods.
